awd_titl_txt: Using Animated Contrasting Cases to Improve Procedural and Conceptual Knowledge in Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to support stronger student outcomes in the teaching and learning of geometry in the middle grades through engaging students in animated contrasting cases of worked examples. Animated contrasting cases are a set of two worked examples for the same geometry problem, approached in different ways.  The animations show the visual moves and annotations students would make in solving the problems. Students are asked to compare and discuss the approaches. This theoretically-grounded approach extends the work of cognitive scientists and mathematics educators who have shown this approach supports strong student learning in algebra. The project will design a series of animated geometry curricular materials on a digital platform that ask students to compare different approaches to solving the same geometry problem. The study will measure changes in students' procedural and conceptual knowledge of geometry after engaging with the materials and will explore the ways in which teachers implement the materials in their classrooms.  This work is particularly important as geometry is an understudied area in mathematics education, and national and international assessments at the middle school level consistently identify geometry as a mathematics content area in which students score the lowest.

This project draws on prior work that documents the impact of comparison on students' learning in algebra. Providing students with opportunities to compare multiple strategies is recommended by a range of mathematics policy documents, as research has shown this approach promotes flexibility and enhances conceptual knowledge and procedural fluency. More specifically, the approach allows students to compare the effectiveness and efficiency of mathematical arguments in the context of problem solving.  An initial pilot study on non-animated contrasting cases in geometry shows promise for the general approach and suggests that animating the cases has the potential for stronger student learning gains. This study will examine the extent to which the animated cases improve students' conceptual and procedural knowledge of geometry and identify factors that relate to changes in knowledge. The project team will develop 24 worked example contrasting cases based on design principles from the prior work in algebra. The materials will be implemented in four treatment classrooms in the first cycle, revised, and then implemented in eight treatment classrooms. Students' written work will be collected along with data on the nature of the classroom discussions and small-group interviews with students. Teachers' perspectives on lessons will also be collected to support revision and strengthening of the materials. Assessments of students' geometry knowledge will be developed using measures with demonstrated validity and reliability to measure changes in student learning.

The Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ACinG Curricular Materials

 

The Animated Contrasting Cases in Geometry (ACinG) project sought to transform the learning of geometry for middle school students by designing a supplementary curriculum  that has students directly compare and contrast solutions to geometry problems, through the use of Worked Example Pairs (WEPs). WEPs depict two fictional students’ solution strategies to a geometry problem side-by-side to allow for the direct comparison of their methods.

 

Animated web-based materials were created for four 8th grade geometry units: informal arguments and angles, transformations, Pythagorean Theorem, and volume. The animated digital materials were designed with careful consideration given to several key features: animations and colors to draw student’s attention to the geometric content in meaningful ways, characters’ solution methods purposefully selected to spark comparisons, the geometric thinking of the WEP characters, and the diversity of characters throughout the units. The animations were built to first present character solutions one at a time, and line-by-line, to allow students to fully understand the strategy before being asked to compare them side-by-side. Coordinated use of colors, blinking animated icons, and specific geometric animations were used to draw students’ attention to important similarities and differences in the strategies. 

 

The curricular materials for each lesson include five unique features: (1) a page for the first character’s solution strategy on a given geometry task, (2) a page for the second character’s solution (to a task which could be the same or different from the first character’s), (3) a page with both character’s strategies side-by-side, (4) a discussion sheet with four questions for the students to answer, and (5) a thought bubble page summarizing the key mathematical concepts in the problem. The discussion sheet and thought bubble page are designed to make the instructional goal of each WEP more explicit and to scaffold discussions among students as they summarize their work from the WEPs.

 

Field-Testing and Revising the Materials

 

The paper-based materials were completed in the spring of 2020, right when the COVID-19 pandemic shut-down schools. The intention was to pilot the paper-based materials in the spring semester at a middle school, as the web-based animations were being created, but unfortunately that was canceled due to COVID-19. Then, the pilot of the web-based materials in the fall of 2020 and spring of 2021 at a middle school was canceled due to COVID-19. Piloting the materials was necessary to inform revisions that needed to be made to the WEPs. The research team pivoted and conducted think aloud interviews with students via Zoom in order to get feedback about both the students’ geometric thinking while engaging with the ACinG materials and their feedback on the design of the materials. Thus, after fully developing the 8th grade geometry materials, 56 hour-long think aloud interviews (with 42 individual students) were conducted and subsequent revisions were made to the animated materials. 

 

Then, in the spring of 2022, a randomized controlled study in five 8th grade math classrooms was conducted to analyze student learning when working on the ACinG project materials. The treatment group received the full set of animated materials with all five pages of the WEP. The control students received the same web-based animated materials; however, they only received each character’s solution separately; they did not receive the compare or thought bubble pages. Additionally, their discussion questions were modified to remove questions asking them to make comparisons. At the completion of the data analysis, more revisions were made to the materials. 

 

Results

 

Analysis of the quantitative data provides evidence that the animated materials improved both the treatment and control students’ knowledge of geometry. This provides evidence of using animated materials for geometry, regardless of treatment type. Further, the treatment group, who directly compared solutions, had stronger performance on open-ended discussion questions and more improved conceptual understanding of the geometry material. These results highlight that animated WEPs can support the learning of geometry content. The ACinG materials promote a new way for learning geometry content that will continue to be made available electronically for implementation by schools across the U.S. These materials show promise to deeply engage students in developing  a deep, connected understanding of geometry.
